results.title: Preparing a cupola for charging
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Foundry Practice”.
Explains how to recognise the end of a heat; the procedure for dropping bottom; and the procedures for preparing a cupola for its next heat.

results.title: Moulding with a three-part flask
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Foundry Practice”.
Use of a deep follow board, techniques of facing, ramming and venting a deep green sand core; how to use a check in a three-part flask; and the purpose and method of step-gating

results.title: Taffy's imagination: fear of the dark
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forest town fables”.
One of a series of six Forest Town Fables, this film presents realistic explanations of imagined fantasies, so that darkness can be faced with confidence. It explains that Taffy is afraid of the dark until her puppet friends teach her their night game. It also shows how she discovers that things she saw and heard were imagined. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Magic scarab: superstition
results.creator_credit: Marshall Izen and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forest town fables”.
This film uses a puppet story to explore the fallacy of belief in superstition, emphasizing self-reliance. It shows how Oni and the other puppets find out whether or not a good-luck charm really works when Oni reluctantly enters the spelling contest without it. Awards: two Emmy awards. Voices by Ruth Franklin and Marshall Izen. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Lost in a crowd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
In this essay on loneliness, five characters in search of someone are sitting on a train. The film shows how each has unsuccessfully tried to remedy their situation. All five share a common problem yet as the train goes down the line not a word is spoken.

group_siblings.title: A Gentle way with cancer no.1

results.title: Birth reborn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
Looks at the work in France of Dr Michael Odent who firmly opposes standard medical thinking on childbirth practices. He advocates that women should be able to give birth in the position in which they feel most comfortable rather than being forced into the “stranded beetle” (legs in stirrups) position commonly used in hospitals. Shows a series of births in which Dr Odent helps women to give birth naturally and with a minimum amount of pain. Also depicts the work of Dr Odent in his pre-birth classes where he encourages women to give birth in different positions: standing or squatting. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.
